item.title: Jane Street Curbed in India After $4.3 Billion Trading Gain
item.description: India’s regulator has temporarily barred Jane Street Group LLC from accessing the local securities market, dealing a severe hit to the US firm that allegedly made $4.3 billion in trading gains in the South Asian nation in less than two years.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi, Bei Hu, Chiranjivi Chakraborty

media:content.media:description: The SEBI building in Mumbai, India.

item.title: Stocks, Futures Slide on Trump’s Tariff Threat: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks fell along with equity-index futures as President Donald Trump ratcheted up trade tensions again ahead of next week’s deadline for higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Oil Drops for Second Day as Traders Brace for Another OPEC+ Hike
item.description: Oil fell for a second day in the lead up to an OPEC+ meeting at the weekend that’s expected to deliver another substantial production hike, threatening to swell a glut that’s forecast for this half.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck, Nicholas Lua

media:content.media:description: The sun rises beyond oil storage tanks at the Enbridge Inc. Cushing storage terminal in Cushing, Oklahoma, U.S., on Wednesday, March 25, 2015. The fastest oil-inventory growth on record at the main U.S. hub may be about to end, easing concern that storage limits will be strained.

item.title: Hong Kong Moves to Defend FX Peg for Third Time in a Week
item.description: Hong Kong authorities intervened for the third time in a week to support the currency, which dropped toward the weak end of its official trading band as the city’s interest rates touched a three-year low.
item.dc:creator: Julia Zhong, Wenjin Lv

media:content.media:description: Hong Kong five-hundred and one-hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, April 23, 2020. Hong Kong's defense of its currency peg to the greenback will likely boost the interbank liquidity pool to a level unseen in two years, lowering local borrowing costs and weakening its dollars.

item.title: The Asia Trade: 7/4/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Tokyo and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Rupee Bond Binge by Indian Firms Poised to Slow After Record Run
item.description: India’s busy local-currency corporate bond market is poised to slow after the country’s central bank hinted room for further rate cuts could be limited.
item.dc:creator: Divya Patil

item.title: Trump May Start Telling Nations New Tariff Rates Soon
item.description: US President Donald Trump said his administration may begin sending letters to trading partners as soon as Friday setting unilateral tariff rates ahead of a July 9 deadline for negotiations. Bloomberg's Jill Disis breaks down his statement on The China Show. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Early Monsoon Rains in India Raise Hopes of a Bumper Grain Crop
item.description: Early and widespread monsoon rains in India have accelerated the sowing of rice, oilseeds and pulses, boosting the country’s chances of record grain harvest this year, according to the farm ministry’s top bureaucrat.
item.dc:creator: Pratik Parija

media:content.media:description: Farmers sow rice saplings at a paddy field in Baghpat, Uttar Pradesh, on June 29. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Iron Ore Gets Second Weekly Boost on Hopes of Supply-Side Reform
item.description: Iron ore headed toward the highest close since May as China’s renewed focus on supply-side reform lifted expectations for the country’s steel market.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell

item.title: Alibaba Raises $1.5 Billion From Sale of Exchangeable Bonds
item.description: Chinese tech giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. raised HK$12 billion ($1.5 billion) from the sale of bonds exchangeable into shares of a unit, Alibaba Health Information Technology Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. headquarters in Hangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: China Vows to Increase Oversight of Wayward Solar Sector
item.description: The Chinese government vowed to increase oversight of the nation’s beleaguered solar industry, which has suffered billions of dollars in losses as an over-abundance of manufacturing capacity slashes prices.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh, Ocean Hou

media:content.media:description: A worker produces photovoltaic modules for solar panels in a factory in Suqian, China.

item.title: Uniqlo Owner, Seven & i To Set Tone for Japan’s Consumer Sector
item.description: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing Co. and Seven & i Holdings Co. will show how Japan’s consumer sector is faring as Asia’s earnings season kicks off.

item.title: US Economy 'Holding Up Relatively Well,' IG Australia Says
item.description: IG Australia's Tony Sycamore says "the US economy seems to be holding up relatively well" and that the House passing the tax bill removes "some uncertainty with regards to the debt ceiling." Sycamore also shares his views on US equities, gold prices, Bitcoin and the Australian dollar. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Goldman Lowers Treasury Yield Forecasts on Rising Fed Cut Bet
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. has lowered its forecasts for US Treasury yields, pointing to the increased likelihood that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates sooner than previously expected.
item.dc:creator: Masaki Kondo

item.title: Trump’s Vietnam Deal Shows China Tariffs Won’t Fall Much Further
item.description: President Donald Trump’s new trade deal with Vietnam sends a clear signal about where US tariffs on Chinese goods might ultimately land, as talks between Washington and Beijing continue following their recent truce.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Lucille Liu

item.title: Fund Bet on Samsung Breakthrough Shows Path for More Kospi Gains
item.description: A peer-beating Asian equity fund is turning its sights on Samsung Electronics Co. amid a rally in Korean equities.
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha

item.title: Lotte E&C’s Bond Gets Limited Buyers After Failed First Attempt
item.description: A construction unit of South Korean conglomerate Lotte Corp. garnered limited institutional buyers for a bond sale that was initially rebuffed by investors, underscoring the financial difficulties the group faces.
item.dc:creator: Haram Lim

media:content.media:description: The Lotte Corp. World Tower. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Singapore Adds Property Measures in Surprise Hit to Market
item.description: Singapore introduced fresh measures to tame housing prices, in a surprise hit to a market that was coming under pressure from renewed economic risks.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Tan, Dexter Low

item.title: First Chinese-Built Aircraft Carrier in Hong Kong
item.description: China's first domestically-built aircraft carrier has docked in Hong Kong, as part of a drive to drum up patriotism in the city. The Shandong will be open to the public this weekend, in what the city's Chief Executive, John Lee, calls an 'inspiring' visit that demonstrates rock-solid national security. Annabelle Droulers has more on how the vessel factors into China's broader naval ambitions. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Set for Weekly Gain as Investors Weigh Rates, Trade Impact
item.description: Gold remained on track for a weekly gain despite falling on Thursday, as investors weighed lower odds for Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts as well as lingering concerns about the outlook for global trade.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

item.title: New World’s Financing Back in Spotlight as Loan Deadline Nears
item.description: Hong Kong developer New World Development Co. is returning to the spotlight this month as investors’ focus turns to its plan to raise as much as $2 billion through a new loan, just days after closing a record refinancing deal.

item.title: Peru Copper Snags Highlight Rising Clout of Informal Miners
item.description: Copper transport disruptions this week in Peru underscore the growing impact of informal mining on global mining corporations that operate in the Andean nation.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

media:content.media:description: A mining truck travels near the MMG Ltd. Las Bambas copper mine in Apurimac, Peru, on Thursday, Sept. 5, 2024. Peru's massive copper deposits are key to meeting growing global demand but a battle has emerged over who gets to mine and sell them.

item.title: US Refiners Rely on Shale More Than Ever as Heavy Oil Supplies Dwindle
item.description: American refiners are relying on oil supplies from the country’s biggest shale basins more than ever as flows of denser varieties from places like Mexico and Canada ebb.

item.title: Treasuries Get Hit as Stocks Jump on Jobs Surprise: Markets Wrap
item.description: Bonds fell and the dollar rose as stronger-than-forecast employment growth soothed concern the US economy is poised to slow, stanching speculation the Federal Reserve will need to cut interest rates any time soon. Stocks hit fresh all-time highs.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: “This is one of the best tactical investment environments,” according to Wei Li, global chief investment strategist at BlackRock, who says her firm still likes US equities.
